fields.value: CBS News/New York Times Texas State Survey, October 1992

dsDescriptionValue.value:
For this survey of Texas residents, questions were posed regarding respondents' vote intentions for the 1992 presidential election, their opinions of the 1992 presidential candidates and their running mates, and the likelihood of their voting in the 1992 presidential election. Additional questions dealt with the national economy, the United States House of Representatives, and whether George Bush, Bill Clinton, and Ross Perot could be trusted to deal with all the problems a president has to deal with. Respondents were also asked to give their approval rating of Bush with respect to his handling of the presidency, foreign policy, and the economy. Background information on respondents includes sex, race, age, education, religious preference, family income, political orientation, party preference, voter
registration status, and vote choices in the 1984 and 1988 presidential elections.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XIV.C.1. Mass Political Behavior and Attitudes, Public Opinion on Political Matters, United States

value: Residents of Texas aged 18 and over having telephones at home.

fields.value: A variation of random-digit dialing using primary sampling units (PSUs) was employed, consisting of blocks of 100 telephone numbers identical through the eighth digit and stratified by geographic region, area code, and size of place. Within households, respondents were selected using a method developed by Leslie Kish and modified by Charles Backstrom and Gerald Hursh (see Backstrom and Hursh, SURVEY RESEARCH [Evanston, IL: Northwestern University Press, 1963]).
Created variable labels and/or value labels.
